Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Separating the Dynamic and Quiescent Corona: A New Tool for the Detection and Analysis of Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team will investigate the dynamic restructuring of the magnetic field and plasma within coronal mass ejections (CMEs) and background solar corona, as CME disturbances propagate and expand through the heliosphere. In this study, the Principal Investigator (PI) will exploit a recently developed technique which enables, for the first time, the isolation of a CME signal from the background corona in space-based and ground-based coronagraph images at fine resolution. By clearly separating the CME disturbance from ambient coronal plasma structures, the PI's team expects to determine the response of the coronal magnetic field and heliospheric plasma to such disturbances.

Using this new method, the PI will greatly improve the detection and classification of CME events, from large CMEs down to faint plasma blobs at the level of instrumental noise, enabling a more detailed statistical study of CMEs. He will also be able to create 3D plasma density maps of the corona over a solar cycle, and such maps will be extremely useful for coronal modeling, for interpreting heliospheric plasma observations, and for direct study of the height of the corona and its temporal evolution.

This investigation of the initiation and propagation of CMEs will increase our understanding of the fundamental properties of astrophysical shock development and propagation in general, and enable the development of predictive tools for when CME disturbances could have a significant impact on the Earth's space environment. The PI's online CME database will be made accessible to the public, with special sections designed for explaining to non-scientists the nature of CMEs and their potential impact on the Earth. The techniques developed here for CME separation and detection will be useful to the wider image processing community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Coronal mass ejections (CMEs) are the largest manifestation of solar activity in the heliosphere. Erupting with huge amounts of energy in the form of plasma and magnetic field, they move through space at millions of kilometers per hour, sweeping up solar wind material and hurtling out towards the Earth and other planets. They often drive adverse space weather effects that can lead to geomagnetic storms on Earth; of detriment to orbiting satellites and technology, manned space-flights, telecommunications, and atmospheric radiation levels (a risk for astronauts and high-altitude flight passengers). To this end, the physics governing their eruption and propagation needs to be understood, and is vital for learning how to predict and forecast their potential impacts on Earth.

This motivated the development of a new, state-of-the-art, coronal image processing algorithm (called CORIMP), to analyze spacecraft imagery for possible CMEs. The Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO) and Solar Terrestrial Relations Observatory (STEREO) missions currently in orbit about the sun provide a wealth of solar observations that allow us to detect and characterize CME structure in the image data, and determine various parameters pertaining to their dynamical evolution, such as their speed, size and trajectory. The CORIMP algorithms provide higher accuracy results than traditionally-used image processing methods, thus allowing a deeper investigation and understanding of the physics of CMEs.

An online catalog of current results is available athttp://alshamess.ifa.hawaii.edu/CORIMP maintained at the Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii. The results are also being prepared for upload to the Heliophysics Event Knowledgebase (HEK) as part of a collaboration with the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO) Feature Finding Team; a team of scientists working on different modules to automatically detect and characterize various aspects of solar activity.
